data.source: Household baseline and endline surveys; administrative records from drug shop transactions; rapid diagnostic test (RDT) results including surprise RDTs; symptoms database linked to RDT outcomes
data.wave_or_subset: Randomized arms: no subsidy; ACT-only subsidies at 92%, 88%, 80%; ACT+RDT subsidies (RDT free or ~85% subsidized, with/without refund). Analyses often focus on first illness episode; some analyses exclude RDT-subsidy households to isolate ACT subsidy effects.
data.sample_size: Approximately 2,789 households; >1,700 drug shop visits recorded; 1,993 observations in certain RDT-related analyses; ~5% attrition at endline
data.unit_of_analysis: Illness episode (primary), with individual- and household-level measures
data.notes: Stratified random sampling by proximity to drug shops and presence of children; surprise RDTs offered to ACT purchasers to measure positivity without selection; symptoms database correlates with RDT results (corr ≈ 0.48); distance to facilities measured; low RDT demand sensitivity to price; robust balance across treatment arms at baseline.

method.description: Randomized controlled trial in Western Kenya varying household access to subsidized ACTs and over-the-counter RDTs to assess impacts on access, targeting, and treatment-seeking behavior. Data were collected via administrative drug shop records, RDT outcomes (including surprise tests), and household surveys. Analyses used regression models with clustered standard errors and fixed effects; a theoretical decision model contextualized expected effects of subsidies.
steps: Conduct baseline survey and stratify households by distance to drug shops and presence of children.
Randomly assign households to subsidy arms: no subsidy; ACT-only at 92%, 88%, or 80%; ACT+RDT with varied RDT pricing/refund options.
Distribute vouchers for ACTs (and RDTs where applicable) and record redemption at participating drug shops.
Implement surprise RDTs among ACT purchasers to estimate malaria positivity without RDT selection bias.
Collect administrative transaction data from drug shops and track RDT uptake and results.
Administer endline survey (~4 months post-intervention) to capture detailed illness episodes and treatment behaviors.

Estimate impacts using regression models with robust standard errors clustered at the household level and relevant fixed effects; adjust for multiple hypotheses using false discovery rate where applicable.
Interpret results alongside a theoretical model of treatment choice under varying subsidy regimes.
method.models: Regression analyses with robust (clustered at household) standard errors and fixed effects; theoretical decision model of treatment choice under price and diagnostic information; simulations of alternative subsidy regimes for under-/over-treatment.
method.outcome_variable: Primary: ACT access/use, targeting of ACTs (malaria positivity among ACT takers), malaria testing (RDT uptake). Secondary: treatment-seeking channel (drug shop vs health center vs no care), antibiotic use, age-specific positivity, over-/under-treatment rates.
method.independent_variables: Indicators for ACT subsidy levels (92%, 88%, 80%), RDT subsidy availability/price/refund, voucher redemption; price levels; demographic factors (age groups, presence of children), distance to facilities.
method.control_variables: Household head age; demographic controls; stratification fixed effects; distance to drug shops/clinics.

results.summary: ACT subsidies substantially increased access to ACTs, primarily via drug shops, without reducing malaria testing. Targeting was weak at very high subsidies (92%), with many ACTs going to malaria-negative individuals, particularly adults. Lowering subsidies (to 80–88%) improved targeting while maintaining access for children. RDT subsidies roughly doubled testing but did not meaningfully reduce ACT overuse in the short run due to partial compliance with negative results. Behavioral responses indicate within-household selection and dose/age-driven price sensitivity, with adults reducing ACT purchases more at lower subsidy levels. Simulations suggest an 80% ACT subsidy can reduce under-treatment and improve welfare relative to no subsidy or very high subsidies, while short-term cost-effectiveness of adding RDT subsidies is limited.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Increase in ACT access with subsidies (range across 80–92%)
Targeting at 92% ACT subsidy (share of ACT takers malaria-positive)
Targeting at 80% ACT subsidy (share of ACT takers malaria-positive)
Adults taking ACTs without malaria (over-treatment among adults at high subsidy)
Increase in visits to drug shops due to ACT subsidies
Reduction in seeking no care (lower bound)
Reduction in seeking no care (upper bound)
Increase in malaria testing with RDT subsidy
RDT voucher redemption rate (when small fee applied)
Change in adult first voucher redemptions (80% vs 92% subsidy)
numerical_results.effect_size: Adult share reduced at lower subsidy

numerical_results.outcome_name: Change in adult ACT redemptions between 92% and 80% subsidy
Share of ACTs at lowest subsidy purchased by malaria-negative individuals
Increase in malaria positivity among ACT takers with RDT subsidy (at highest ACT subsidy)
numerical_results.effect_size: Improved targeting on the intensive margin

numerical_results.outcome_name: Total share taking ACT (selected experimental setup)
numerical_results.effect_size: Increase from 0.190 to 0.385 vs no subsidy scenario

numerical_results.outcome_name: Targeting of ACTs at drug shops
numerical_results.effect_size: Higher targeting at drug shops relative to health centers (assumptions vary)

metadata.original_paper_title: Price Subsidies, Diagnostic Tests, and Targeting of Malaria Treatment: Evidence from a Randomized Controlled Trial
